text: hi everyone welcome to IGCSE study buddy
where you can revise biology topics from
the Cambridge IGCSE syllabus
this video summarizes part one of topic
7 human nutrition
humans need different nutrients to
survive
to get the correct amounts of these
nutrients a balanced diet must be eaten
a balanced diet consists of all of the
food groups in the correct proportions
let's take a look at the nutrients that
are essential for humans
carbohydrates provide energy for
respiration in cells
examples of carbohydrates include rice
pasta and potatoes
the next food group is fats and oils
fats are used as long-term stores of
energy
also a layer of fat Under the Skin acts
as insulation
cheese fatty meats and butter are
examples of fats
all cells contain protein so it is a
vital substance for growth and repair of
tissues
proteins are found in fish meat and eggs
vitamin C maintains healthy skin and
gums
a vitamin C deficiency causes a disease
called scurvy where wounds don't heal
and there is excessive bleeding
vitamin C is found in citrus fruits like
oranges and lemons
vitamin D helps the body absorb calcium
which is needed for strong bones and
teeth
a vitamin D deficiency leads to a
condition called rickets that causes
weak and soft bones as well as
deformities
dairy products fish oil and eggs contain
vitamin D
mineral ions like calcium are also
essential for human nutrition
calcium is needed for strong and healthy
bones and teeth
it also has a role in blood clotting
milk cheese and eggs are examples of
foods rich in calcium
iron which is another important mineral
is needed to make hemoglobin which is
present in red blood cells and help
carry oxygen around the body
iron is found in red meat and some green
vegetables like spinach
fiber or roughage helps food to move
through the stomach and intestines
it is found in vegetables fruits and
whole grains
water is needed for chemical reactions
to take place in cells
in addition to plain water water can be
obtained from both drinks and food
moving on to the digestive system let's
learn about how the food we eat is
broken down and used by our body
the role of the digestive system is to
break down large insoluble molecules
into smaller soluble food molecules to
provide the body with nutrients
let's take a look at the parts of the
digestive system
this is the mouth
this part is called the esophagus
this is the stomach
this is the small intestine
this is a large intestine
this is the rectum
and this is the anus
all these organs are part of the
elementary canal
the associated organs of the digestive
system are
the salivary glands
the pancreas
the liver
and the gall bladder
the small and large intestines have
different paths
the duodenum is the first part of the
small intestine
the ilium is the second part of the
small intestine
the colon makes up the larger part of
the large intestine
the rectum and anus are also parts of
the large intestine
next let's take a look at the different
functions of the organs of the digestive
system
ingestion is the taking of substances
example food and drink into the body
basically eating or drinking
digestion is the breakdown of food
absorption is the movement of nutrients
from the intestines into the blood that
is when the nutrients move from the
digestive system into the circulatory
system
assimilation is the uptake and use of
nutrients by cells so that is when the
nutrients move from the circulatory
system to the cells
and ejection is the removal of
undigested food from the body as feces
digestion can be subdivided into
physical digestion and chemical
digestion
physical digestion is the breakdown of
food into smaller pieces without
chemical change to the food molecules
physical digestion increases the surface
area of food for the action of enzymes
in chemical digestion
so food gets more surface area for the
enzymes to act on
physical digestion is mainly carried out
by the teeth in the mouth
the stomach and the bile in the duodenum
let's learn the different types of teeth
a human has
incisors
canines
primolars and molars
the differing shapes and sizes of teeth
enable them to perform slightly
different functions
incisors are for biting and cutting
canines are for tearing holding and
biting
and free molars and molars are for
chewing and grinding
the structure of a tooth
this is the enamel
this is the dentine
this is the pulp cavity
these are nerves
these are blood vessels
this is called cement
the tooth is embedded in bone
and gums
physical digestion takes place in the
stomach as well
physical digestion occurs as the stomach
walls squeeze the food to liquefy it
the lining of the stomach contains
muscles which contract to physically
squeeze and mix the food with the strong
digestive juices that are present in the
stomach
bile also plays an important role in
physical digestion
the liver is where bile is produced
bile is stored in the gall bladder
it is released through the bile duct
into the duodenum which is the first
part of the small intestine
bile is a greenish Brown fluid which
helps in digestion
it is made by the liver and stored in
the gall bladder
bile is secreted into the duodenum
through the bile duct for two reasons
it is alkaline so it neutralizes the
hydrochloric acid which comes from the
stomach
it breaks down large drops of fat into
smaller ones this is known as
emulsification
so as you can see a large drop of fat is
emulsified by the bile to give smaller
fat droplets to increase the surface
area for chemical digestion
that concludes part 1 of chapter 7 human
nutrition
hope you found this video useful thank
you for watching and please don't forget
to subscribe to IGCSE study buddy for
more biology revision videos bye
